turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Barry, I'm fucking broke!  I know we used to fuck with anyone who asked for anything we didn't like, but it's gotta stop.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Bullshit.  The guy was going to buy one record -- which we didn't even have -- and leave and never come back again anyway.  Why not have a little fun?  Big fucking deal.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What did he ever do to you?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: He offended me with his terrible taste.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: It wasn't even his terrible taste. It was his daughter's.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Oh, now you're defending that motherfucker?  You're going soft in your old age, Rob.  There was a time when you would have chased him out of the store and up the street.  Now all of a sudden I'm offending your golf buddy.  You're right, Rob.  I am so sorry. How are we ever going to make enough money to get you and Laura into the country club?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: But now I kind of like it.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: I wanna date a musician...

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I wanna live with a musician.  She'd write songs at home, ask me what she thought of them, maybe even include one of our private jokes in the liner notes.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: ...Maybe a picture of me in the liner notes...

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What did you tell her about the shop for?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: I didn't know it was classified information.  I mean, I know we don't have any customers, but I thought that was a bad thing, not, like, a business strategy.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: We're only on the fucking list for Marie's gig at the Pulaski Pub, that's all!  All three of us.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: That's fucking great, Barry.  We can spend fifteen bucks on a cab to save five each.  Fantastic, Barry!

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: We can take your car.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: It's not my car, now is it?  It's Laura's car, and thus Laura has it. So it's an ass-bumping double- transferring bus ride through bumblefuck or a fat wad on a cab. Wow.  Fucking great.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What do you mean, "what?"

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: What are you snickering about?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'm not snickering.  I'm smiling. Because I'm happy.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: What am I missing?  What do you have to be happy about?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Okay.  Top five side one track ones. Number one... "Janie Jones," the Clash, from The Clash.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Ehh.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: "Thunder Road," Bruce Springsteen, from Born to Run. "Smells Like Teen Spirit," Nirvana, Nevermind.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Oh no, Rob, that's not obvious enough. Not at all.  Dick, did you hear that?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Shut up. "Let's Get It On," Marvin Gaye, from Let's Get It On. "Airbag," Radiohead, from OK Computer.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Ooh!  A kind of recent record!  Rob's sly declaration of new classic-status slipped into a list of old classics! Nice! "Let's Get It On?" Couldn't you make it more obvious than that?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: There's something different about the sound of her voice... And what did she mean last night, she hasn't slept with him yet.  Yet.  What does "yet" mean, anyway?  "I haven't seen... Evil Dead II yet." What does that mean?  It means you're going to go, doesn't it?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: -- You're like a little squirrel of music, storing away dead little nuts of old garbage music, musical lint, old shit, shit, shit --

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: -- Barry, if I were to say to you I haven't seen Evil Dead II yet, what would that mean?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Just... come on, what would it mean to you?  That sentence? "I haven't seen Evil Dead II yet?"

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: To me, it would mean that you're a liar.  You saw it twice.  Once with Laura -- oops -- once with me and Dick.  We had that conversation about the possibilities of the guy making ammo off-screen in the Fourteenth Century.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, I know.  But say I hadn't seen it and I said to you, "I haven't seen Evil Dead II yet," what would you think?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: I'd think you were a cinematic idiot. And I'd feel sorry for you.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No, but would you think, from that one sentence.  That I was going to see it?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: I'm sorry, Rob, but I'm struggling here.  I don't understand any part of this conversation.  You're asking me what I would think if you told me that you hadn't seen a film that you've seen.  What am I supposed to say?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Just listen to me.  If I said to you --

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: "-- I haven't seen Evil Dead II yet," yeah, yeah, I hear you --

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Would you... would you get the impression that I wanted to see it?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Well... you couldn't have been desperate to see it, otherwise you'd have already gone...

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: ...But the word "yet..." Yeah, you know what, I'd get the impression that you wanted to see it.  Otherwise you'd say you didn't really want to.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: But in your opinion, would I definitely go?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: How the fuck am I supposed to know that?  You might get sick of people telling you you've really gotta go see the movie.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Why would they care?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Because it's a brilliant film.  It's funny, violent, and the soundtrack kicks fucking ass.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: I never thought I would say this, but can I go work now?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Let's pack it up.  We haven't had a customer in four hours.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Fine by me.  I still want pay to 7 o'clock.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Ha.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Un-fucking-believable.  Dick's out on a hot date, Rob's boning Marie LaSalle, and the best-looking and most intelligent of all of us isn't getting anything at all.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: How do you know about that?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Oh come on, Rob.  What am I, an idiot? I'm more bothered by Dick's thing. How did this happen, Dick?  What rational explanation can there possibly be?  What's her name?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Shut the fuck up, Barry.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Yeah, you would say that, wouldn't you?  You two have to stick together now.  Boners United.  United in getting some.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Don't be sad, Barry.  You'll find true love someday.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Suck my ass.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Terrific.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Hey.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What the fuck is that?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: My band.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What band?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: The band that found me and asked me to join.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You are not in a band, Barry.  You are not a musician.  And no posters.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Thanks for your support, Rob.  Really appreciate it.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Barrytown.  Barrytown?  Is there no end to your arrogance?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: I didn't make up the name.  It's the Steely Dan song.  And it was in The Commitments.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You can't be called Barry and sing in a group called Barrytown.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: They were fucking called that before I was in it, okay?  It wasn't my idea.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: That's why you got the gig, isn't it?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Isn't it?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: That was one of the reasons they asked me to join originally, yes. But --

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Great!  That's fucking great!  They only asked you to sing because of your name!  You can stick it above the browser racks over there.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: How many tickets can I put you down for?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: None.  Christ!

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: You're not even coming?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Of course I'm not coming.  Do I look like I'd want to listen to some terrible experimental racket played in some hideous cave?  Where is it?  The fucking Bucktown Pub?  Ha!

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: So much for friends, then.  You're a bitter bastard, Rob, you know that?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Bitter?  Because I'm not in Barrytown? You should be shot like a lame horse, you jerk.  Just keep that out of my window.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: What's up?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Laura.  Her dad died.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Ooh.  Drag.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: It was Jan, and it was a long time after--

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Whatever.  Okay. "Tell Laura I Love Her." That'd bring the house down. Laura's mom could sing it.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Fuck off, Barry.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: I'd want "One Step Beyond" by Madness. And "You Can't Always Get What You Want."

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Because it's in The Big Chill.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Haven't seen it.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Liar.  We saw it in the Lawrence Kasdan double-bill with Body Heat.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Oh.  Right.  But I'd forgotten about that.  I wasn't biting the idea.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Not really.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: The little skate-fuckers.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No way.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Yes way.  It's really...

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: What the fuck is that?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: I heard you, man.  Don't give me that "what" shit.  You just told them that you're gonna put out a record with them.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: So?  You even said they're good.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: HELLO.  DO YOU SEE ANYONE ELSE around here with a band, Mr. Branson?  Mr. Phil Spector?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Like fuck you are.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Laura said we could.  If we helped out with the posters and stuff.  And we did.  And we are.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'll give you 10% of the door if you don't play.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: We're getting that anyway.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What is she doing?  Okay, 20%.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: No.  We need the gig.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: 110%.  That's my final offer.  I'm not kidding.  That's how much it means to me not to hear you play.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: We're not as bad as you think, Rob.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You couldn't be.  Look, Barry. There's going to be people from Laura's work there, people who own dogs and babies and Tina Turner albums.  How are you going to cope with them?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: We're not called Barrytown anymore, by the by.  They got sick of the Barry/Barrytown thing.  We're called SDM.  Sonic Death Monkey.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Sonic Death Monkey.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: What do you think?  Dick likes it.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Barry, you're over thirty years old. You owe it to yourself and your friends and to your parents not to sing in a group called Sonic Death Monkey.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: I owe it to myself to go right to the edge, Rob, and this group does exactly that.  Over the edge, in fact.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You'll be going over the fucking edge if you come anywhere near me next Friday night.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: That's what we want.  Reaction.  And if Laura's bourgeois lawyer friends can't take it, then fuck 'em.  Let 'em riot, we can handle it.  We'll be ready.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: I'm looking for a record for my daughter.  For her birthday.  "I Just Called To Say I Love You." Do you have it?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Oh yeah.  We got it.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Great.  Can I have it then?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: No, you can't.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Because it's sentimental tacky crap, that's why not.  Do we look like the kind of store that sells "I Just Called To Say I Loved You?" Go to the mall and stop wasting our time.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: What's your problem?  What did I... Why are you --

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Do you even know your daughter? There is no way she likes that song. Or is she in a coma?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: It's almost impossible to find, especially on CD.  Yet another cruel trick on all of the dumbasses who got rid of their turntables.  But every other Echo and the Bunnymen album --

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: I have all of the others.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Oh really.  Well what about the first Jesus and Mary Chain?

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: They always seemed...

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: They always seemed what?  They always seemed really great, is what they always seemed.  They picked up where your precious Echo left off, and you're sitting here complaining about no more Echo albums.  I can't believe that you don't own that record. That's insane.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Well what about the new Echo --

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Do not get ahead of yourself.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: That is perverse.  Do not tell anyone you don't own fucking Blonde on Blonde.  What about Television?

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: I have a television.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: NO--!

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Holy Shiite!  What the fuck's this?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: It's the new --

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Mitch Ryder and the Detroit Wheels?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: No.  The Righteous Brothers.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Oh well.  Nevermind.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: No, not nothing.  What's wrong with the Righteous Brothers?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Nothing.  I just prefer the other one.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Bullshit.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: She shouldn't done it on "The Number Four With a Smile."

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Isn't her album called "Number Four With A Smile?"

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: That's what I said.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: No, no, no, you said "The Number Four With a Smile," and there's no "The" at the front of the title of the album.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: It's a reference to a Chinese meal in Toronto and I think that there is a "The."  But I could be wrong.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: You can be and are wrong.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: He's got one!

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: On Clark Street!

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: A couple blocks!  About six!

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: We work there!

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: You'd love it!

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: I can't go to the club tonight, guys.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Who are you going to see?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Nobody.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Anna.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Anna who?  Anna Green Gables?  Anna Conda?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Anna Moss.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Anna Moss.  Mossy.  The Mossy Thing. The Swamp Thing.  Is she all green and furry?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Don't do it, Rob!

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: He's not worth it!

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Okay, okay -- "Leader of the Pack." The guy fucking cracks up on a cycle and dies right? "Dead Man's Curve," Jan and Dean...

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Did you know that after that song was recorded, Jan himself crashed his --

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: -- It was Dean, you fucking idiot.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: "Somebody's Gonna Die" by Blitz. "Bella Lugosi's Dead," Bauhaus. It's got that creepy Halloween feeling.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: No.  No.  Mom wants you to come to the funeral.  It's on Friday.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Hey, Barry.

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Oh, hi.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Where's Rob?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: The Malcolm McClaren of Clark Street is in his executive suite.  Do you have an appointment?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: BARRY
turns.text: Just that Rob seems to think it would be wiser to start a record label by putting out a record with business- crippling Nazi Youth shoplifters than with someone he knows in his bitter jealous heart is a musical visionary.  That's all.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: May I help you?

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: I'm looking for Deejay Rob Gordon.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Uh.  That's me.

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: I'm Caroline Fortis from The Reader. I want to do a story on you.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Right.  Why?

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: Well, I used to go to the Dodger on your nights, and I saw you're doing it again and that your putting out a record, and it's sort of a then-and- now story against the backdrop of the Chicago music scene with the emphasis on now.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Oh.  Okay.

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: I thought I would ask you a few questions if that's okay.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Huh.  You used to come to the club? I shouldn't have let you in.  You must have only been about sixteen.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What I mean is, I didn't mean you look young.  You don't.  You don't look old either.  You look just as old as you are.  A bit younger maybe, but not a lot.  Not much.  Just right.

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: So.  Is now a good time?

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: Right.  So.  You must have an enormous record collection.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Yeah.  I could show it to you if you want to come over and see it.

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: Yeah, well... Let's see... What are you're all-time top five records?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Pardon me?

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: Your desert island top-five.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Oh boy... In the club, or at home?

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: Is there a difference?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: OF COURSE... Well yeah, a bit. "Sin City" by the Flying Burrito Brothers is an all-time top five, but I wouldn't play it at the club.  It's a country-rock ballad.  Everybody'd go home.

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: Nevermind.  Any five.  So four more.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What do you mean, four more?

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: Well if one of them is this "Sin City" thing --

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Can I go home and work this out and let you know?  In a week or so?

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: Look if you can't think of anything, it doesn't matter.  I'll do one.  My five favorite from the old days at the Dodger.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Oh, I'm sure I can manage something... "Sin City." "New Rose," by The Damned. "Hit It and Quit It" by Funkadelic. "Shipbuilding," Elvis Costello, Japanese import, no horns, or different horns, anyway... um... "Mystery Train" by Elvis Presley... And... "Spaced Cowboy" by Sly and the Family Stone.  A bit controversial, I know, but...

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: Fine.  That's great.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Is that it?

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: Well, I wouldn't mind a quick chat, if you got the time.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Sure, but is that it for the list?

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: That's five.  So.  Why did you decide to deejay again?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Well it was a friend's idea, really, and the record release party seemed like a good place to do it.  So...  I should really put a James Brown in there --

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: Nice friend.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: What's his name?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Who?  Oh.  My friend.  My friend is Laura.  A girl.  A friend who's a girl.

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: "Music for Old People." What does that mean?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Look, I'm sorry about this, but I'd like "the Upsetter" by Lee "Scratch" Perry, in there.  Instead of "Sin City."

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: Okay. "Dance Music For Old People?"

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Oh, you know... a lot of people aren't too old for clubs but they're too old for acid jazz and garage and ambient and all that.  They want to hear old funk and Stax and New Wave and Old School Hip Hop and some new stuff all together and there's nowhere for them.

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: And the new label?  And the Kinky Wizards?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Oh, well, the Kinky Wizards are -- you know what?  Why don't I just make you a tape?

turns.speaker: CAROLINE
turns.text: Would you?  Really?  Wow.  I could have deejay Rob Gordon play in my own home.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Haha.  Right.  It's no problem.  I love making tapes.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Rob, hi, so sorry I missed your call. In LA on business.  You know how it gets.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Yeah, sure...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Good.  Great.  Yeah... Wow.  Rob Gordon.  Seems like a 100 million years ago now.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Yeah.  A billion.  Right... How are you?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Fantastic but I'm a little busy right now.  Listen.  Do you want to come to dinner Saturday?  I'm having some friends over and I need a spare man. Are you a spare man?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Uh...yes, at the moment.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Great.  Gotta go.  See you then.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Hey Charlie.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Hey Rob.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Why did you break up with me for Marco?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Fuck!  I knew it!  You're going through one of those what-does-it- all-mean things.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: There's been a rash of them, recently. I find it a little unnerving.  In fact Marco called a few months back, and he wanted to see me, and rehash the past as they say, and I wasn't really up for it.  Do all men go through this?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: C'mon, just answer the question. You can say what you like.  What the hell?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: It's all kind of lost in the... in the dense mists of time now... It wasn't that I really liked Marco more.  In fact I thought you were more, shall we say, attractive than him.  It was just that he knew he was good-looking and you didn't, and that made a difference somehow.  You used to act as if I was weird for wanting to spend time with you, and that got kind of beat, if you know what I mean.  Your self-image started to rub off on me and I ended up thinking that I was strange.  And I knew that you were kind and thoughtful... you made me laugh, and I dug the way you got consumed by things you loved... and Marco seemed a bit more, I don't know, glamorous? More sure of himself?  Less hard work, because I felt like I was dragging you around, sort of.  A little sunnier.  Sparkier.  I don't know.  You know what people are like at that age.  They make very superficial judgements.  Do you think that's superficial?  He was a clown, if it's any consolation.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Did you tell that to Marco when he did his what-does-it-all-mean thing with you?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Oh God, no.  I didn't want to hurt his feelings.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: 'Morning, Dick.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Oh, hi.  Hi, Rob.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Good weekend?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Yeah, OK.  I found the first Licorice Comfits album at Vintage Vinyl.  The one on Testament of Youth.  Never released here.  Japanese import only.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Great.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: I'll tape it for you.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No, that's okay.  Really.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: 'Cause you like their second one, you said, Pop, Girls. etc.  The one with Cheryl Ladd on the cover.  You didn't see the cover though.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Yeah, I haven't really absorbed that one.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Well, I'll just make it for you.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: The new Belle and Sebastian.  Like it?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Hey.  Didn't you steal that one already?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Can I help you?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Are you all right?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Yeah.  I'm sorry... Look Dick, Laura and I broke up.  She's gone.  And if we ever see Barry again maybe you can tell him that.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: 'Course I will, Rob.  No problem. No problem at all.  I'll tell him next time I see him.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: I've ah... got some other stuff to tell him anyway, so it's no problem. I'll just tell him about, you know, Laura, when I tell him the other stuff.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: I'll start with your news before I tell him mine, obviously.  Mine isn't much, really, just about Marie LaSalle  playing at Lounge Ax tonight.  I like her, you know, she's kind of Sheryl Crowish... but, you know, good.  So I'll tell him before that. Good news and bad news kind of thing.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Or rather, bad news and good news, because he likes this person playing tonight.  I mean, he liked Laura too, I didn't mean that.  And he likes you.  It's just that --

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I understand, Dick.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Sure.  'Course.  Rob, look.  Do you want to... talk about it, that kind of thing?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I always hated this song.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Let's not.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: I want a tape.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Rob.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Liz, hold on a second --  What?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Marie LaSalle is in the store!  Here, she's here, and now!

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Rob --!

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: -- FUCK OFF!

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I will now sell four copies of Cats and Dogs by the Royal Trux.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Do it.  Do it.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Well we rang $900 today.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Yeah but more than that.  I'm happy because I'm proud of us.  Because although our talents are small and peculiar, we use them to their best advantage.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Don't worry about it, Dick.  Barry's an asshole.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: Yeah... Well... I'll see you tomorrow, Rob.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: I'm sorry, Rob, that's, it's --

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You're a horrible person, Barry.  I mean it.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Can I do anything?

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: "Abraham, Martin, and John." That's a nice one.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What is this.

turns.speaker: DICK
turns.text: It's Vince and Justin.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Who's that?

turns.speaker: IAN
turns.text: Laura?  Are you okay?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I am fine...  I gotta go.  Goodbye.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Yeah, I'm fine.  I'm off the phone.

turns.speaker: IAN
turns.text: You look upset.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I'm upset, but I'm fine.

turns.speaker: IAN
turns.text: Maybe I should talk to him.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Mmmm, no.  Not a good idea.

turns.speaker: IAN
turns.text: Conflict resolution is my job, Laura.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Nothing to resolve, Ian.  Let's get a drink.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Can I help you?

turns.speaker: IAN
turns.text: Hello, Rob.  Remember me?  I'm Ray. Ian.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What needs sorting out?

turns.speaker: IAN
turns.text: Come on, Rob.  My relationship with Laura has obviously disturbed you a great deal.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Funnily enough I haven't been too thrilled about it.

turns.speaker: IAN
turns.text: We are not talking jokey understatement here, Rob.  We're talking actionable harassment.  Ten phone calls a night, hanging around outside my house...

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Yeah, well, I've stopped all that now.

turns.speaker: IAN
turns.text: We've noticed and we're glad.  But, you know... how are we going to make peace here?  We want to make things easier for you.  What can we do? Obviously I know how special Laura is, and I know things can't be good for you at the moment.  I'd hate it if I lost her.  But I'd like to think that if she decided she didn't want to see me anymore, I'd respect that decision.  Do you see what I'm saying?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: IAN
turns.text: Good.  So shall we leave it at that then?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I dunno.

turns.speaker: IAN
turns.text: Think about it, Rob.

turns.speaker: IAN
turns.text: Good.  So shall we leave it at that then?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I've already left it, you pathetic rebound fuck!  Now get your patchouli stink out of my store.

turns.speaker: IAN
turns.text: Good.  So shall we leave it at that then?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: We won't leave it, Ian.  Not ever.

turns.speaker: IAN
turns.text: So shall we leave it at that then?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I dunno.

turns.speaker: IAN
turns.text: Think about it, Rob.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You don't have to go this second. You can stay until whenever.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: We've done the hard part now.  I might as well, you know...

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Well stay for tonight, then.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Jeez.  He goes on long enough.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I should be so lucky.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Shit!

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I thought I could give you a lift back.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Are you coming home?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Yes.  Well, I'm coming over to your house to get some things.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: My house?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: How can you like Art Garfunkel and Marvin Gaye?  It's like saying you support the Israelis and the Palestinians.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: It's not like saying that at all, actually, Rob.  Art Garfunkel and Marvin Gaye make pop records --

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: -- Made.  Made.  Marvin Gaye is dead, his father shot him in --

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: -- whatever, and the Israelis and the Palestinians don't.  Art Garfunkel and Marvin Gaye are not engaged in a bitter territorial dispute, and the Israelis and the Palestinians are. Art Garfunkel and Marvin Gaye --

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: -- Alright, alright but --

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: -- and who says I like Marvin Gaye, anyway?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Hey!  Marvin Gaye! "Got to Give It Up!" That's our song!  Marvin Gaye is responsible for our entire relationship!

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Is that right?  I'd like a word with him.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: But don't you remember?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I remember the song.  I just couldn't remember who sang it.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You used to care more about things like Marvin Gaye than you do now. When I first met you, and I made you that tape, you loved it.  You said -- and I quote -- "It was so good it made you ashamed of your record collection."

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Well, I liked you.  You were a deejay, and I thought you were hot, and I didn't have a boyfriend, and I wanted one.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: So you weren't interested in music at all?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Yeah, sure.  More so then than I am now.  That's life though, isn't it?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: But Laura... that's me.  That's all there is to me.  There isn't anything else.  If you've lost interest in that, you've lost interest in everything.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: You really believe that?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Yes.  Look at me.  Look at our -- the apartment.  What else do I have, other than records and CDs?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: And do you like it that way?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Not really.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Have you tackled the Great Reorganization yet?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Don't you think there are more important things to talk about than my record collection?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: So.  Where have you been staying for the last week?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I think you know that.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Had to work it out for myself, though, didn't I?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I'm sorry.  I haven't been very fair to you.  That's why I came here to the store this evening.  I feel terrible, Rob.  This is really hard, you know.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Good.  So.  Is it my job?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: What?  Gimme a fucking break.  Is that what you think?  That your not big enough a deal for me?  Jesus, gimme a little credit, Rob.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I don't know.  It's one of the things I thought of.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: What were the others?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Just the obvious stuff.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: What's the obvious stuff?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I guess it's not that obvious, then.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What, what?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Did you say something?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No.  So.  Is it working out with Ian?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Rob.  Don't be childish.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Why is that childish?  Your living with the guy!  I'm just asking how it's going.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I am not living with him.  I've just been staying with him for a few days until I work out what I'm doing. Look, this has nothing to do with anyone else.  You know that, don't you?  I left because we weren't exactly getting along, and we weren't talking about it.  And I suddenly realized that I like my job, and I like what my life is could be turning into, and that I'm getting to a point where I want to get my shit together and I can't really see that ever happening with you, and yeah, yeah, I sort of get interested in someone else, and that went further than it should have, so it seemed like a good time to go.  But I have no idea what will happen with Ian in the long run.  Probably nothing.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Well then why don't you quit it while you seem to not be ahead?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Look.  Maybe you'll grow up and we'll get it together, you and me.  Maybe I'll never see either of you again. I don't know.  All I know is that it's not a good time to be living here.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: So, what, you haven't definitely decide to dump me?  There's still a chance we'll get back together?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Well, if you don't know, there's a chance, right?  It's like, if someone was in the hospital and he was seriously ill and the doctor said, I don't know if he's got a chance of survival or not, then that doesn't mean the patient's definitely going to die, now does it?  It means he might live.  Even if it's only a remote possibility.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I suppose so.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: So we have a chance of getting back together again.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Oh, Rob, shut up.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Hey, I just want to know where I stand.  What chance --

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: -- I don't fucking know what chance you fucking have!

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Well if you could tell me roughly it would help.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Okay, okay, we have a nine percent chance of getting back together. Does that clarify the situation?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Yeah.  Great.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I'm too tired for this now.  I know I'm asking a lot, but will you take off for a while so I can get my stuff packed up?  I need to be able to think while I do it and I can't think while you're here.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No problem.  If I can ask one question.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Fine.  One.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: It sounds stupid.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Nevermind.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You won't like it.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Just ask it!

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Is it better?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Is what better?  Better than what?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Well.  Sex, I guess.  Is sex with him better?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Jesus Christ, Rob.  Is that really what's bothering you?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Of course it is.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: You really think it would make a difference either way?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Well the answer is that I don't know either.  We haven't done it yet.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Never?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I haven't felt like it.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: But not even before, when he was living upstairs?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: No.  I was living with you, remember? We've slept together but we haven't made love.  Not yet.  But I'll tell you one thing.  The sleeping together is better.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: The sleeping together is better but not the sex because you haven't done it was him yet.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Will you please just go?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Hi.  I've been looking for an envelope of my receipts from last month and I'm thinking I didn't take them with me.  Have you seen them around?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'll look for 'em.  How you doing?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I'm sorry to call, but I need that stuff...

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Fine, I'm sure it's in the file at home.  I'll call you when I find it, and then we'll talk.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: We'll talk some other time.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Great... That's great.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: So, how are you?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Have you slept with him yet?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I told you I slept with him.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No, not -- I mean have you, you know --

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Is that why you wanted to see me?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I guess.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Oh, Rob.  What do you want me to say?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I want you to say that you haven't, and I want it to be the truth.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You kind of have to start with Elvis Costello, but where? "Motel Matches?" "I Want You?" "I Hope You're Happy Now?" "Green Shirt?" His records should be sealed in cases that say "in case of vicious betrayal, smash glass." "Where Did You Sleep Last Night," sure, but by Robert Johnson or by Nirvana?  Maybe a Liz Phair track.  There are a couple to get angry at instead of being angry with. Some devil's advocate stuff.  The Silver Jews could be good when you're ready to start putting it all behind you...  But I think we're getting ahead of ourselves there.  Ah.  Dylan. Bob fucking Dylan.  Now Bob Dylan would --The phone rings.  He pulls off his headphones and picks it up but says nothing.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: You must have known it would happen. You couldn't have been entirely unprepared.  Like you said, I've been living with the guy.  We were bound to get around to it sometime.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: And anyway, I keep trying to tell you, that's not really the point, is it?  The point is we got ourselves into an awful mess, Rob...  Are you there?  What are you thinking?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: We can meet for another drink if you want.  So I can explain it better. I owe you that much.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Look, I gotta go.  I work too, you know.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Will you call me?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I don't have your number.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Call me at work.  We can arrange to meet properly.  I don't want this to be the last conversation we have.  I know what you're like.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You do, huh.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: It's me.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I figured it was.  Where are you?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I think the big question here is where are you, if you don't mind my saying so, and I think I know where you are.  You're running.  On the run.  You're running from a point that everyone hits in any relationship, and you're just going to hit it again with Ian but it's going to be with a World Music bunny- rabbit-looking earth-shoe-wearing "Doctor Who"-watching twit who doesn't really understand you, not the way that I do and will more in the future, and you'll have just wasted more time and arrive in the exact same place that you're in now, only later. And with... him.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I'm not -- hold on...

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Are you still in love with me?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Jesus.  I do not know.  I'll talk to you later.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Think about what I said.  I mean, if you want to experiment, or whatever --

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I'm not experimenting.  Why don't you go experiment.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I don't want to.  Don't need to.  I love you.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: You don't ever think about other people?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No... not really... I mean, I think about it... but no, I don't really think about it.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I called and called but you were out.  I thought I'd be gone before you got back.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Is that the last of it?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Yep.  I might have missed some stuff. I'm so used to some things being here that I don't even notice them.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Those look heavy.  Where's Ian?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: He's at home.  Listen, I can't believe he went to the store.  I'm mortified, actually.  I'm really sorry.  He had no right to do that, and I told him so.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: It was kind of funny.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I'm sure.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You still together?  Going all right?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I don't really want to talk about it, to be honest.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: That bad, eh?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: You know what I mean.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Fix it up.  It'll make you feel better.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'll bet you can't remember what you were doing here, can you?  I mean, how much are you making now?  Sixty? Seventy?  And you were living in this shitty place.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: You know I didn't mind.  And it's not as if Ray's place is any better.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'm sorry, but can we get this straight?  What is his fucking name, Ian or Ray?  What do you call him?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Ray.  I hate Ian.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I hate him too.  So I just call him "Mavis." Or "Sissyboy." Or "Mavis the Sissyboy."

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: This is where you're supposed to say that you haven't laughed this much in ages, and then you see the error of your ways.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: You make me laugh much more than Ray does, if that's what you're getting at.  But I already knew you could make me laugh.  It's everything else I don't know about.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You know I'm a good person.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Mmm hmm.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You know that I can cook my ass off when I feel like it.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Oh ho, so very infrequently.
